para.emphasis: The Life and Work of J.D. Salinger

passage.para: Writer J. D. Salinger will always be remembered for his most famous character, Holden Caulfield. The protagonist of the novel The Catcher in the Rye, Caulfield became the voice of disaffected youth not only for his generation-those coming of age in the early 1950s-but for generations to come. The struggle to reconcile innocence and youth with the pressures and expectations of the wider world is a theme that runs not only through Salinger's work, but his life as well.

Jerome David Salinger was born in New York City in 1919 to an upper-middle class family. His father was a manager in a successful cheese and meat importing company. As an adolescent, Salinger attended public schools as well as a military academy. He dropped out of several colleges in New York, opting instead to immerse himself in the Greenwich Village literary scene. This route paid off for Salinger; he had his first work published in 1940 in Story magazine, after making the acquaintance of some of New York's most prestigious editors.

Salinger's literary career, however, soon took a back seat to events overseas. Despite a mild heart condition, Salinger volunteered to fight in World War II and was sent to serve in Europe. One of the few bright spots during his time in Europe was meeting the writer Ernest Hemingway, with whom Salinger developed a lasting correspondence.

While Salinger's experience of the war certainly left him traumatized, when he returned to New York, he more or less picked up where he left off. Before the war, he had started writing a series of stories about a young man who suffers a nervous breakdown in the middle of Manhattan. These would later form the basis for Salinger's first and only novel, The Catcher in the Rye, published in 1951.

Parallels between Holden Caulfield's and Salinger's lives are evident, especially as far as their educational careers are concerned. The Catcher in the Rye begins with Caulfield on the verge of expulsion from boarding school, after already having been kicked out of two previous schools. He leaves his prestigious New England prep school for a two-day adventure in New York City, and meets characters from walks of life he had never encountered within his privileged milieu.
What drew the acclaim of critics and readers alike was the authenticity of Caulfield's inner
monologue. He is shown to be not just a "'rebel without a cause," but a thoughtful and clever
young man, astutely critical of society and its "'phoniness," yet at the same time, desiring
acceptance from it. Some critics have gone so far as to suggest that Holden Caulfield was the archetype for modern "bad boy" culture heroes such as James Dean.

Salinger would go on to publish numerous other stories in The New Yorker over the next decade. The most famous of them, published in book form in 1961, was Franny and Zooey, about the relationship between a gifted brother and sister who, each in their own way, struggle with the expectations of maturity. Other noteworthy stories written in this period include: Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymore, an Introduction.

After Hapsworth 16, 1924 was published in 1965, Salinger mysteriously withdrew from the public eye. Living more or less as a recluse in rural New Hampshire, Salinger has ceased to submit anything for publication, and rarely, if ever, gives interviews.

Some observers suspect that Salinger's withdrawal from society is indicative of a mental breakdown of some sort; in this respect, at least, perhaps Salinger has much more in common with his maladjusted characters than most people may have realized.

question-stem.para: The word disaffectedin the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: condemned
alienated
complicated
despised

explanation.para: Disaffected means resentful against authority. Alienated means estranged or separated from
others, which is similar in meaning. The clue to meaning is in paragraph 1: "'the struggle to
reconcile." Although the young people were emotionally (C) complicated and may hove (D) despised authority, these words are not synonyms of disaffected. (D) condemned is incorrect.

question-stem.para: The word acclaim in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: disdain
criticism
interest
praise

explanation.para: Praise is a synonym of acclaim. The clue to meaning is in the same sentence: "'authenticity,"
which means Salinger created a believable character. This can only be accomplished by a
good writer and would be worthy of praise, (A) Disdain and (8) criticism are opposite in meaning. (C) Interest implies no judgment; the job of a critic is to judge.

question-stem.para: The word astutely in the passage is closest in meaning to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: shrewdly
unnecessarily
silently
significantly

explanation.para: Astutely and shrewdly are synonyms, both meaning perceptive. The clue to meaning is in the same sentence : Caulfield is a "thoughtful and clever" young man who is "'critical of

. .. ;" offering thoughtful criticism is a result of perception. Caulfield is not (C) silent (quiet) in his criticism . (B) Unnecessarily critical would imply there was no real reason to be critical, which is not true.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, one of the main themes that concerned J.D. Salinger was

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: the difficulties young people faced as they entered adulthood
the pressures society placed on individuals to conform
the ability of a single individual to change a society
the importance of serving those in need

explanation.para: Paragraph 1 states that the theme running throughout Salinger's work was that of youth struggling to reconcile innocence with the expectations of the world (A). Examples of these struggles in his work are noted in paragraphs 5 and 7. Items (B) and (C) are elements of Salinger's work, but are too narrow in scope. (D) is not mentioned in the passage.

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: graduated from New York University
attended a private high school
dropped out of high school
did not finish college

explanation.para: This detail is presented in paragraph 2: "He dropped out of several colleges ... " To "drop out" is to leave before finishing (D). (A) is attractive because he went to colleges in New York but it doesn't say he went to New York University; (B) is attractive because a military academy can be confused with private school-in addition, Caulfield attended a private school; (C) is attractive because he did "drop out" of school, but it was college, not high school.

question-stem.para: According to the passage, Holden Caulfield is similar to J .D. Salinger in that

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: he is about the same age
he wants to be a writer
he has attended several different schools
he is interested in popular culture

explanation.para: This detail (C) is presented in paragraph 5, where the "parallel" between the writer and his character's educational career is noted. (A) is attractive because Caulfield's struggles occurred at the same age as Salinger's. (B) is noted only about Salinger. (D) is attractive because they both struggle with culture and fitting in, which is not the same as showing an "interest" (detached observation) in popular culture.

question-stem.para: It can be inferred that Salinger was considered

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: unstable
rebellious
a model citizen
a hero for youth

explanation.para: (A) Unstable in this context means having a lack of emotional control. The author states in the last paragraph that some people suspect Salinger became a recluse because he'd had a mental breakdown. (B) is attractive because Salinger dropped out of school and his characters were rebellious. (C) is attractive because Salinger's character Caulfield became an "archetype," which is a model or prototype. (D) is attractive because
Salinger created the archetype for a "culture hero."

question-stem.para: The author recounts the plot of The Catcher in the Rye in paragraph 5 in order to
Paragraph 5 is marked with an arrow [].

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: make the passage more entertaining
illustrate a similarity between Caulfield and Salinger
demonstrate how unconventional the novel was
support the claim that the novel's protagonist revolutionized popular culture

explanation.para: In sentence 1 of paragraph 5 the author states that there are parallels between the lives of Salinger and Caulfield (B). After the plot is summarized, it is left to the reader to relate these events to Salinger's life in paragraph 2. The concepts of entertainment (A), unconventionality (B), and revolution (D) are not noted in paragraph 5.

question-stem.para: There are four squares [ ] in the passage. These squares represent places where the sentence below could be added to the passage.

para.emphasis: The horrors and tragedies of what he saw there affected him deeply.

question-stem.para: Where would the sentence best fit?
Click on the square [ ] in the passage where the sentence fits the best.

insert-sentence.sentence: The horrors and tragedies of what he saw there affected him deeply.

explanation.para: In this passage, the noun phrase "horrors and tragedies of what he saw there" could only apply to war, which is the topic of the sentence preceding (C). Also, the word there implies place, which is another clue to establishing coherence. The "places" noted in the other three positions are not related to war: (A) Salinger's lie; (B) Greenwich Village; (D) New York.

question-stem.para: The word These in the passage refers to

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: Salinger's war experiences
Salinger's literary influences
Stories Salinger began writing before the war
Publishers to whom Salinger submitted his work.

explanation.para: The pronominal referent must precede the word these and must "form the basis" (or foundation) of Salinger's novel. Stories form the foundation of a book. A "series of stories" (C) is noted in the preceding sentence. His war experiences (A) were mentioned too early in the paragraph to be a referent for these. Neither publishers (D) nor literary influences (B) are mentioned in the passage.

question-stem.para: Which of the following best expresses the essential information in the highlighted sentence in the passage? Incorrect choices change the meaning in important ways or leave out essential information

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: After The Catcher in the Rye, popular culture became more appreciative of rebellious, troubled figures.
Despite the example set by Holden Caulfield, youth heroes became more rebellious.
Holden Caulfield was inspired by figures like James Dean.
The Catcher in the Rye was based loosely on events in the life of James Dean.

explanation.para: Essential information noted in the highlighted sentence includes "bad boy" which means a rebellious, troubled figure, and "modern ... culture," which means popular culture (A). That Salinger's bad boy archetype became a culture hero implies the culture appreciated (liked) the archetype. The other choices are incorrect because they do not paraphrase the sentence nor they are not true.

question-stem.para: Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the author's opinion about J.D. Salinger?

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He is the most important author of the twentieth century.
He imitated the style of Ernest Hemingway.
His short stories are much stronger than his novels.
His troubled characters are based on his own experiences.

explanation.para: The author parallels Salinger's life with Caulfield's in paragraph 5. In paragraph 1 it is stated that the theme of reconciling innocence with reality runs through both Salinger's work and life. It is stated in paragraph 9 that Salinger had in common with his characters a mental breakdown. All of these details make (D) the correct answer. None of the other choices are true, although each contains an element that is mentioned: Salinger is an acclaimed author, corresponds with Hemmingway, and writes short stories

question-stem.para: Directions: The sentence below is an introductory sentence for a short summary of the passage. Select THREE answer choices from the chart that represent important ideas in the passage. Some sentences are incorrect because they contain information that was not in the passage or contain information that is a minor detail. This question is worth 2 points.

para.emphasis: J.D. Salinger is an important figure in American literature.

question-stem.para: Use the mouse to drag the answer choices to the spaces where they belong. To remove an answer; choice, click on it. To look at the reading passage again, click on 'View Text.'

answer-choice-set.answer-choice: He created a memorable character who defined a generation.
He is considered the founder of a new genre of literature
The life of his most famous character paralleled that of his own.
The language used by his characters became the language of youth culture.
Contemporary critics considered his use of inner monologue as a literary device revolutionary
After a prosperous writing career, he withdrew from public life.

explanation.para: (A) Salinger's character who defined a generation is noted in paragraph 1. (C) That Caulfield paralleled his own life is noted in paragraph 5. (F) That Salinger withdrew from public life is noted in the last paragraph.

(B) is attractive because Salinger's character established an archetype, but this is not the same as creating a new genre of literature. (D) is incorrect because Salinger's writing captured the voice of disaffected youth, it did not create a new mode of expression. (E) is incorrect because Salinger masterfully used this device, he did not revolutionize (change) it.
